com.uttt.common.board

Class Position

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.uttt.common.board.Position
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Playable

    public final class Position
extends java.lang.Object
implements Playable
    A Position represents a (row,col) location within a specific board.

    Postion's are immutable, and are fully validated at construction (e.g. exception if null board, row/col out of range).

      • isPlayable

        public boolean isPlayable()
        Description copied from interface: Playable
        Return true iff the associated Position refers to an open token spot, or an open board. A board, in turn, is open iff no win has been acheived at its own field level and there is at least one (resursively) open position in its field.
        Specified by:
        isPlayable in interface Playable

      • depth

        public int depth()
        Calculates how many levels deep the position is from the top-board. Positions within the top-board itself are always depth=1, while the bottom-boards are always depth=(top-board-height).

      • deref

        public <T extends Node> T deref(java.lang.Class<T> typeClass)
        Boilerplate reduction, allowing: 
        Type t = pos.deref(Type.class)
        rather than: 
        Type t = pos.getBoard().getSubNode(pos.getRow(), pos.getCow(), Type.class)
        See Also:
        derefBoard(), derefToken()

      • derefBoard

        public Board derefBoard()

        rather than

      • at

        public Position at(int subRow,
                   int subCol)
            throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Return a newly constructed Position instance that refers to the (row,col) within the board this position refers to.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If this position is already at a bottom-board; If (row,col) fails range checking;

      • place

        public Position place(Token t)
               throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Place the given Token on the location this position references. Such board must be a bottom-board (i.e. of height=1), and the board must be in a playable state (i.e. neither in a "win" state for either player, nor in a draw state).

        Placing a token will result in a next-move-constraint, meaning some board position within the game which limits the freedom of the next play. The derivation of the next-move-constaint is influenced by the game's rules-variant, but generally follows a two phase process: first, the current move and current board state are combined to yeild a tentative bottom-board as constraint. Second, if that board is not playable (i.e. is already in a win or draw state), the constraint shifts up to the parent board. This "if not playable, then shift to parent" logic continues until a playable board is found, or until reaching the top-board. If at the top-board, then the constraint is considered "null" (and is, in fact, represented by a null value).

        Parameters:
        t - The player token to place.
        Returns:
        The next-move-constraint, as a Postion.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - When the board is has a height greater than 1 (i.e. is not a bottom-board); The position is not actually playable, because either the token-spot is already taken, or the spot's lineage is not playable.
